instructions.title: 1st Passage: Unwrapping the Past (Paper)
instructions.prompt: For this passage, you will read the content in paper form (attached to a tablet). You will answer a series of questions in the computer while reading the passage in the tablet. As you answer questions, you will NOT be able to return to previous questions. Make sure before proceeding to the next question that your answer is final.

questions.prompt: Write a brief summary of the reading. Include A) the main idea of the passage, B) a list of key points, and C) any other relevant information you might remember. You may list your thoughts in phrases or sentences. There is no need to write a paragraph.
What is this article mainly about?
answers: Why the ancient Egyptians made mummies
What the study of mummies can teach us
Where an ancient Egyptian mummy was found
How researchers unwrap mummies

questions.prompt: According to the text, why do experts study mummies with the help of high-tech tools?
answers: They know Ancient Egyptian civilization was an important time in history.
There are millions of mummies to learn from.
Mummies have been puzzles and these tools help them solve the puzzles.
They can learn more information about the past and solve modern medical mysteries.

questions.prompt: A mummy is a dead body that has been preserved with special chemicals and wrapped in cloth.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: It takes multiple steps to make a mummy. All of the following are steps to make a mummy EXCEPT
answers: A dead body is wrapped in cloth.
Organs are removed.
Special chemicals are put on the body.
Detailed coffins or cases are made.
A special outfit is created.

questions.prompt: True or False: The Egyptians would mummify animals like cats and dogs.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: Why did the Egyptians create mummies?
answers: To protect their loved ones after death
To leave clues for future generations about their life
To celebrate the lives of their loved ones
To help scientists and researchers

questions.prompt: How is the Ancient Egyptian tradition of mummification related to their beliefs?
answers: The mummification process preserves one’s body for the afterlife.
The mummification process celebrates and honors the lives of loved ones.
The mummification process documents important information about Ancient Egyptian civilization.
The mummification process provides future generations with critical information that can be used to solve present problems.

questions.prompt: According to the article, what did scientists in the past do to study mummies?
answers: They looked through microscopes.
They analyzed food remains.
They cut through the bodies.
They soaked the bodies in chemicals.

questions.prompt: What do scientists do now to study mummies?
answers: Travel internationally
Use X-rays to model the mummies insides
Collaborate at academic conferences
Carbon date materials

questions.prompt: True or False: Scientists can tell about the diet of mummies when they were living.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: About how many years ago did Hatshepsut live?
answers: 5000 years ago
3500 years ago
350 years ago
50 years ago

questions.prompt: The article states that Ancient Egyptian civilization began about 5,100 years ago. Based on the information in the text, Queen Hatshepsut was one of the first pharaohs.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: On page 2, the article says that Queen Hatshepsut reigned in Egypt. This means that Hatshepsut:
answers: was the ruler of Egypt
took control illegally
treated Egyptians unfairly
had a very long life

questions.prompt: How did scientists identify Hatshepsut's mummy?
answers: They used the results of DNA testing.
They found her family tomb.
They located her husband's remains.
They decoded the writing on her mummy case.

questions.prompt: According to the text, Queen Hatshepsut 'stole the throne and declared herself a pharoah. She even dressed as a man.' What do you think the author included these details in the text?
answers: To show how rare it was for Queen Hatshepsut to be a pharoah, or Egyptian King
To show clues to look for in terms of identifying Queen Hatshepsut’s mummy
To show how DNA evidence might be helpful in identifying Queen Hatshepsut
To show that Queen Hatshepsut became Queen illegally

questions.prompt: Scientists think the study of mummies could someday help to make sick people better. Which of the following explains why?
answers: Because the chemicals that Ancient Egyptians put on the mummies tell us about illnesses
Because mummies had ancient illnesses
The mummification process preserved medicines and cures that were used in Egyptian times.
Researchers learn what diseases infected ancient people to understand how diseases have changed over time.

questions.prompt: According to the text, studying mummies teaches us about the past and present. Why do you think researchers focus on studying mummies versus other artifacts from other ancient civilizations?
answers: Ancient Egyptian civilization began 5,100 years ago, so mummies are particularly old artifacts.
The mummification process preserves the bodies from decomposing making it easier to study the mummies and the diseases the infected them.
Queen Hatshepsut was a particularly important figure and the first female ruler, making studying her mummy important.
The detailed coffins, or cases, show the sophisticated civilization that existed in Ancient Egypt and from which we can learn a lot.

questions.prompt: Bob Brier says that 'mummies are crucial to medical science.' Brier means that:
answers: scientists are surprised about what mummies can teach them
research on mummies should be done only by doctors
scientists are worried that mummies may bring back old diseases
information about mummies is very important to doctors.

questions.prompt: In the last paragraph, what does Bob Brier mean by the phrase 'to read' a mummy?
answers: To understand the words written on a mummy
To visit museum exhibitions about mummies
To gather information by examining a mummy
To make sense of the stories about mummies

questions.prompt: Which of the following sentences says why Hatshepsut is considered a powerful female ruler?
answers: Hatshepsut reigned more than 3,500 years ago- as queen and king.
She first served as queen until her husband died.
She stole the throne and declared herself a pharaoh.
She even dressed as a man.
After Hatshepsut' death, her mummy mysteriously disappeared from its tomb.

instructions.title: 2nd Passage: Suffrage (Digital)
instructions.prompt: For this passage, you will read the content in digital form (in the computer). You will answer a series of questions in the computer. As you answer questions, you will NOT be able to return to previous questions. Make sure before proceeding to the next question that your answer is final.

questions.prompt: Write a brief summary of the reading. Include A) the main idea of the passage, B) a list of key points, and C) any other relevant information you might remember. You may list your thoughts in phrases or sentences. There is no need to write a paragraph.
What is the main purpose of this text?
answers: To describe the events leading to the passage of the 19th Amendment
To identify the states that first supported women’s voting rights
To discuss the most important leaders of the suffragist movement in the 1800s
To explain why the equal Rights Amendment has not been ratified

questions.prompt: According to the text, why did Abigail Adams warn the Founding Fathers to “remember the ladies”?
answers: She knew 1776 was an important time in US history.
She wanted a more equal government.
She warned that women would rebel and not follow laws made where women did not have a say.
She thought women were smart and could guide improve laws and government.

questions.prompt: What was the constitutional amendment that gave women the right to vote in all elections?
answers: 1st amendment
5th amendment
12th amendment
19th amendment
Equal Rights amendment

questions.prompt: About how many years did it take after the Declaration of Independence for women to earn the right to vote in every state?
answers: 10 years
50 years
100 years
150 years
200 years

questions.prompt: In terms of women’s suffrage, what is a key difference between the Declaration of Independence and the 19th Amendment?
answers: One gave equal rights to men and the other gave voting rights to all.
One gave men voting rights and the other gave women voting rights.
One gave men equal rights and the other gave women equal rights.
One happened in history and the other happened recently.

questions.prompt: According to the article, what was most surprising about the 'Womanifesto'?
answers: It was written by Elizabeth Cady Stanton.
It called for equal voting rights for men and women.
It was based on the Declaration of Independence.
It had such a large number of resolutions.

questions.prompt: When Elizabeth Cady Stanton wrote the Womanifesto, why did she demand equal voting rights rather than other rights like property ownership?
answers: It was patterned on the Declaration of Independence which showed that universal suffrage was important.
She wanted to shock people and get more attention for the important cause
She realized that being able to vote meant that women could have a say in making laws that could get them more rights.
She thought it would encourage more individuals to join the Women’s suffrage movement.

questions.prompt: The article says that women in the suffrage movement 'pressed their case state by state.' This means that the women:
answers: spoke with newspaper reporters in many states.
strongly urged the states to pass women's suffrage.
traveled in large groups together from state to state.
introduced the idea of women's suffrage to the states.

questions.prompt: Women could vote in certain territories and state elections before they could vote nationally.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: Which was the first state or territory to pass a law allowing women to vote?
answers: New York
Wyomying
Tennessee
Pennsylvania
Washington, DC

questions.prompt: Why was the Wyoming Territory the first state or territory to give women the right to vote?
answers: Because the small number of women there would not have had much political influence
Because the suffragist movement was very active in the western United States
Because most politicians there chose not to vote on that resolution
Because it was important for women to have the vote in such a dangerous area

questions.prompt: The following were factors that contributed to the women’s suffrage movement EXCEPT
answers: Women organized at the Women’s Rights Convention.
Women demonstrated and picketed.
More women were graduating and working outside the home.
A constitutional amendment passed easily to gather support.

questions.prompt: The text states that 'In 1878, a constitutional amendment was introduced…in 1887, the Senate voted against it.' What can you infer from that information?
answers: The amendment established equal voting rights for all and support was mixed.
The amendment established equal rights for all and had strong support.
The amendment established equal voting rights for all, but had declining support.
The amendment established equal voting rights and had increasing support.

questions.prompt: After marches and protests, President Woodrow Wilson supported the 19th amendment.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: What state played a key role in passing the 19th amendment because it was the final state needed to approve the amendment?
answers: New York
Wyoming
Tennessee
Pennsylvania
Washington, DC

questions.prompt: Both houses of Congress voted to change the Constitution in which year?
Once the 19th amendment passed, the women’s suffrage movement took off, with the Equal Rights Amendment being passed shortly thereafter.
answers: True
False

questions.prompt: When was the first election where more women than men voted?

instructions.title: 3rd Passage: MOOCA (Digital)
instructions.prompt: For these passage, you will read the content in digital form (in the computer). For the MOOCA, each question correspond to a passage. As you answer questions, you will NOT be able to return to previous questions. Make sure before proceeding to the next question that your answer is final.

questions.prompt: For Passage #1, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Polgar felt empowered to challenge Kasparov's views on traditional gender stereotypes.
Polgar wanted to become the youngest grandmaster chess player and travel the world to play.
Polgar proved her critics wrong by being the first woman to beat him in a match in 2002.

questions.prompt: For Passage #2, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: People like to drink coffee because caffeine is a stimulant in the body and can make people feel mentally aware and physically alert.
When the body digests caffeine, the body produces a chemical that prevents the development of unhealthy tissue related to liver disease.
Determining why the world’s most popular beverage, coffee, provides benefits that prevent liver disease is challenging for scientists.

questions.prompt: For Passage #3, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: For example, a liver was eventually successfully donated from one twin and transplanted to the other.
So, a transplant replaces failing organs with new organs from other people or animals.
Ultimately, a rejection to an organ transplant due to a person’s autoimmune system could be fatal.

questions.prompt: For Passage #4, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Patients appreciate it when nurses impart their medical knowledge and pay extra attention to help them comprehend their care.
Importantly, patients who do not understand their education will likely not follow treatment plans or use medical services correctly.
So, nurses need to provide quality education to help prevent and avoid additional illnesses and injuries during treatment.

questions.prompt: For Passage #5, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Gender roles have changed over time that led to more rights for women such as suffrage rights and employment rights, but progression of these rights has not always been linear, consistent, or permanent.

The second wave of feminism did not necessarily have far reaching effects on gender roles outside of the US, or even in all areas within the US, but the Equal Rights Amendment was passed in 1972 by Congress.
In the mid-1960s, Betty Friedan’s book, “The Feminine Mystique,” revealed the details of the average discontented housewife and oppressive decision making by men in power such as in advertising.

instructions.title: 4th Passage: MOOCA (Paper)
instructions.prompt: For these passages, you will read the content in paper form (attached to a tablet). You will answer a series of questions in the computer while reading the passage in the tablet. For the MOOCA, each question correspond to a passage. As you answer questions, you will NOT be able to return to previous questions. Make sure before proceeding to the next question that your answer is final.

questions.prompt: For Passage #6, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: These perceived threats of the sympathetic nervous system could result in  an increased chance of a heart attack, increasing need for breathing.
The structure of the divided nervous system allows people to feel differently depending on the state of the breath and body.
Consciously taking a deep breath slows respiration and signals the nervous system to suppress the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.prompt: For Passage #7, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Asexual organisms include bacteria, hydras, and flatworms, but some plants that reproduce sexually can also reproduce asexually.
Since offspring of living organisms share genetic material of their parents, the biological process is referred to as reproduction.
Because each asexual organism can reproduce on their own, they tend to reproduce more quickly than sexual organisms.

questions.prompt: For Passage #8, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Interactions between humans are needed through communication, social gatherings, and dating.
New social media platforms may have a sole focus with a specific function such as text, photos, or video.
Interactions become so stimulating at times that people continue them for as long as possible.

questions.prompt: For Passage #9, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: Healthy soil is important for all food crops to grow, but not all types of food crops grow in the identical types or combinations of soil materials.
Fortunately, our food supply system including green houses and transportation is diverse enough to support and ship a diverse range or crops.
The soil moisture level a plant thrives in depends on the plant structure, the geographic location where the planet grows, and the nutrients the plant needs.

questions.prompt: For Passage #10, select the best sentence to complete the story
answers: People who use devices with capacitive touchscreens need to avoid pressing on the screen with too much pressure.
The types of touch screens that are most accepted to use with electronic devices are resistive and capacitive touch screens.
A plastic stylus works on a resistive touch screen, but not a capacitive because plastic insulates electrical current.
